course_title: Introduction to Philosophy: What is Philosophy?

learning_outcomes.description: Understand some of the central debates in philosophy (breadth and depth)
Demonstrate basic skills of effective thinking and communication (clarity, relevance, accuracy)
Conduct independent philosophical research and inquiry
Identify, analyse and evaluate arguments or points of view
Understand the role of philosophy in everyday life

assessments.due_date:
6/03/2025 - 22/05/2025

Tutorials run during weeks 2-12, with no tutorial in week 8.
assessments.task_description: Students discuss the set reading for the relevant week. Marks are credited for participation, which includes demonstration of reading the set text and contribution to a community of philosophical inquiry (see marking and criteria). Tutorials run during weeks 2-12 (with no tutorial in week 8) and are face-to-face. This is an in-person assessment not permitting use of AI.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Students will respond to set piece based on the philosophers of weeks 2-4 (Plato, Boethius, Aquinas). Students are required to write a 300 word analysis and critique of the piece, evaluating the content using their own individual judgement and perspective. Further details are available on the Blackboard site under 'Assessment'.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) provides emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI use may constitute student misconduct under the student code of conduct.

A word count that is within ±10% of the set length (word limit) is acceptable. Word count does not include footnotes; however, discursive footnotes are included in the word count. A word count that is outside these 10% will receive a proportionate penalty and will be graded against the grading criteria.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignments must be submitted via TurnItIn (on Blackboard); please check that your submission has been received.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Students are required to write a philosophical essay on a topic from Part I of the course. Topics are specified in detail in the essay task sheet on Blackboard. Maximum word count: 1000 words (includes discursive footnotes but excludes references and bibliography). For this assignment you may use any recognised referencing style, though you must be consistent throughout.

A word count that is within ±10% of the set length (word limit) is acceptable. Word count does not include footnotes; however, discursive footnotes are included in the word count. A word count that is outside these 10% will receive a proportionate penalty and will be graded against the grading criteria.

This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI). Students are advised that the use of AI technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignments must be submitted via TurnItIn (on Blackboard); please check that your submission has been received.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Students are required to write a philosophical essay on a topic from Part II of the course. Topics are specified in detail in the essay task sheet on Blackboard. Maximum word count: 1200 words (includes discursive footnotes but excludes references and bibliography). For this assignment you may use any recognised referencing style, though you must be consistent throughout.

A word count that is within ±10% of the set length (word limit) is acceptable. Word count does not include footnotes; however, discursive footnotes are included in the word count. A word count that is outside these 10% will receive a proportionate penalty and will be graded against the grading criteria.

This assessment task evaluates student's abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of Artificial Intelligence (AI). Students are advised that the use of AI technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignments must be submitted via TurnItIn (on Blackboard); please check that your submission has been received.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
What is Philosophy?

An introduction to philosophy and the course.


Learning outcomes: L05
learning_activities.topic_description: What is Philosophy? An introduction to philosophy and the course.

learning_activities.topic:
10 x one hour tutorials

Choose one tutorial time from the options on Si-Net. Tutorials will be held weeks 2-7 and 9-12.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: 10 x one hour tutorials Choose one tutorial time from the options on Si-Net. Tutorials will be held weeks 2-7 and 9-12.

learning_activities.topic:
Philosophy and Love

Plato's Symposium and the ladder of love.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Philosophy and Love Plato's Symposium and the ladder of love.

learning_activities.topic:
Philosophy and Life

Boethius and the consolation of philosophy.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Philosophy and Life Boethius and the consolation of philosophy.

learning_activities.topic:
Philosophy and God

Thomas Aquinas and theology.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Philosophy and God Thomas Aquinas and theology.

learning_activities.topic:
Philosophy and Truth

Descartes' Meditations, scepticism, and self-knowledge.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Philosophy and Truth Descartes' Meditations, scepticism, and self-knowledge.

learning_activities.topic:
Philosophy and Reality

Descartes' Meditations, the external world, and the mind/body problem.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Philosophy and Reality Descartes' Meditations, the external world, and the mind/body problem.

learning_activities.topic:
Philosophy and Knowledge

Hume's Essay, empiricism, and the problem of induction

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Philosophy and Knowledge Hume's Essay, empiricism, and the problem of induction

learning_activities.topic:
Philosophy and Suspicion

Introduction to 20th century European philosophy with Marx, Nietzsche, and Freud on false consciousness and the fate of philosophy without Truth.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Philosophy and Suspicion Introduction to 20th century European philosophy with Marx, Nietzsche, and Freud on false consciousness and the fate of philosophy without Truth.

learning_activities.topic:
Philosophy and Absurdity

Albert Camus’ The Myth of Sisyphus on affirming life in the face of an absurd, meaningless universe.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Philosophy and Absurdity Albert Camus’ The Myth of Sisyphus on affirming life in the face of an absurd, meaningless universe.

learning_activities.topic:
Philosophy and Freedom

Introduction to existentialism with Jean-Paul Sartre’s “Existentialism is a Humanism” on human existence, freedom, and our relation to the Other.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Philosophy and Freedom Introduction to existentialism with Jean-Paul Sartre’s “Existentialism is a Humanism” on human existence, freedom, and our relation to the Other.

learning_activities.topic:
Philosophy and Gender

Feminist existentialism with Simone de Beauvoir’s The Second Sex and thinking about the philosophical condition of Woman under patriarchy.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Philosophy and Gender Feminist existentialism with Simone de Beauvoir’s The Second Sex and thinking about the philosophical condition of Woman under patriarchy.

learning_activities.topic:
Philosophy and Race

Black existentialism with Franz Fanon’s Black Skin, White Masks, critiquing white philosophy and examining lived experience under racism.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Philosophy and Race Black existentialism with Franz Fanon’s Black Skin, White Masks, critiquing white philosophy and examining lived experience under racism.

learning_activities.topic:
Philosophy and Embodiment

Merleau-Ponty’s phenomenology of the body in The Phenomenology of Perception and thinking through the racialised body in Hokowhitu’s Indigenous existentialism.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Philosophy and Embodiment Merleau-Ponty’s phenomenology of the body in The Phenomenology of Perception and thinking through the racialised body in Hokowhitu’s Indigenous existentialism.
